This is why we typically do it at night, so that by the morning it has all absorbed and she isn't so slippery/greasy, but it can make it a little tough to wrangle her into her PJs. It also leaves my hands feeling quite greasy, but does pretty easily wash off.

We also use this as our daughter's "boo-boo" cream. Anytime we notice a scratch or a small cut, we dab this on it after bath. I find that this helps with the healing process very nicely, keeping the little boo-boo moist and protected.

review name: Amazing results for not just diaper rashes but for baby eczema as well
review text: I have been using Aquaphor baby ointment for about 3 years now for both my kids who have eczema. I tried other products specifically focused as eczema creams but nothing beats Aquaphor. I did hear that Aquaphor baby and regular Aquaphor regular are exactly the same. But that has never stopped me from ordering just the baby version for my kids.

review name: I don't like that this product is vaseline-like

I had heard so much about this, everyone raving, so I thought I'd try it for my son who gets rashes easily in our dry, cold winter weather. I can't say I've really seen a difference in his rash just from this product, as many times when I use it, I also use hydrocortisone cream to help with his itching. My issue is this product is a bit expensive and the main ingredient is petroleum jelly! Which is super cheap comparatively. The texture of the aquaphor ointment is like that of petroleum jelly, as well. I'm not super impressed with this product.
This came highly recommend by my dermatologist . It‚Äôs a wonderful product if you have dry skin

review name: best E.V.E.R. I'd give 1,000 stars if I could
review text:
I have been buying aquaphor aquaphor ever since I had my first baby. We do NOT use anything else and would never even consider using another product. Aquaphor is literally a staple in my home. I used it for both of my children, I used it when my first had cradle cap (and on my second baby's noggin so she never had cradle cap!) I use this on my daughter who has eczema when she has a break out, my husband uses it in the summer when he's gets a heat rash from working out in the heat, I use it on my hands after dishes or in the winter....I literally give this in every baby basket I ever make for showers. I have convinced several people to switch after hearing about their baby's horrific diaper rash....and the #1 reason I LOVE it:
Through diaper explosions, excessive diarrhea, pooping at nap time and I didn't know before she fell asleep, 12 hour sleep seessions during teething...my oldest NEVER...NEVER (not even once) had a diaper rash.

Buy back products many times

I use this on both my children whenever their skin needs extra moisture. It was actually recommended by our pediatrician's office which also supplied me with some coupons to take $$ off the product. During the 3 years that I have used this these are the highlights of what I've learnt:

* Apply just enough, don't slobber it over. This stuff is pretty sticky and will make a baby sweat if you cake it on her/him.
* Apply this at nighttime after a bath. Since it tends to get sticky, this stuff will catch lint or dirt if you put it on a baby and let them play during day time. The other option is to keep your house super-duper clean unlike mine and if so, more power to you!
* Use it as a foot cream during winter, apply on washed feet and put on a sock to keep perfect summer-ready toes and heels, at winter time. How cool is that?
* This will not heal dermatitis. If you think it's making any skin rash worse, do not apply. Consult your doctor before you use this over ANY skin rash.
* This is a great lip balm too, try it!

Although a bit on the pricey side, one jar of this lasts a long time as long as we don't treat it like jam on bread. Overall I like it.

It's easier to get ointment on your finger using one hand to open the jar. With tubes I felt like I needed both hands to open it and squeeze out the ointment onto my figure while with the tub I can open it with one hand and get some without let going of my child's scrambling legs. review name: Skin relief for the whole family
review text:
Forget baby, Aquaphor healing ointment works on skin problems for all skin types. We use this tub religiously to take care of cracked cuticles in the winter, after household maintenance leaves hands rough, and for rough, scaly skin from crawling around the floor at daycare. Notably we do not use it to deal with diaper rash, as you'll want a separate one from a multipurpose tin.

Aquaphor comes out thick and suspiciously slippery, hinting at the formula's potency. For deep healing and moisturizing, dab this stuff on generously and wear a pair of cotton gloves or socks to sleep. The thick compound will linger on your skin for hours, even when rubbed in to the point the top layer of your epidermis ought to be worn off. It carries very little scent to speak of except when concentrated in the tin, and even that has a neutral pleasant quality.

The results speak for themselves. Chapped, reddened skin turns a soft pink. The worst scaly elbows and knees won't stand up to two days of applied care. I've got highly sensitive skin and Aquaphor never generates a reaction for me. Mineral oil and ceresin, the primary two ingredients, are practically inert as far as I'm concerned. The concoction is up for handling eczema and terrible diaper rash right down to soothing a paper cut, and it will hold up through active handwashing with plenty of soap.

Aquaphor is an essential in the home medicine cabinet, and if you're from any kind of cold winter climate, get this. At the risk of sounding like a fan girl, I'll say it makes a huge difference if you have dried skin. Don't suffer in pain when you don't have to.

I would apply it on her forehead once a day and her flaky skin disappeared after a few days to a week. Then I noticed she had flaky skin on the top of her scalp as well so I started putting some on top. It gave her a rather unattractive look of hair grease on top (picture a balding clown) and afterwards, the skin on top actually began flaking off like bits of dandruff but I think it's getting a little better. Hopefully she won't need this hair gel for long...

If not for skin issues, I use it as a baby diaper cream with disposable diapers. Since I use predominately cloth diapers, which petroleum jelly isn't recommended for, I feel like this tub will last a long while....

review text:
I use Aquaphor for many things including lip balm, foot balm, hand cream, or body cream in general. Especially for my dry hands which get a few dozen washes a day, it works wonders!

During the past, I always buy the smaller tubes because I thought smaller tubes are better for traveling. There's only one problem with Aquaphor which is very common for ointments: it melts in hot temperature. When I travel to countries with hot weather, one squeeze on the small tube will pump out half an oz of oil. I also have to double zip-bag them during traveling. Because I had to bad luck of buying a half-empty tube once (purchased new with manufacture's seal intact), and repetitive leaky small tubes during traveling in hot weather, I decided to try the large Aquaphor jar. It turns out the big jar has the same Aquaphor that works just as well. Surprise! (wink)

For traveling, I have learnt to decant Aquaphor to another small container which has better sealing. And the occasional Amazon coupon and subscribe & save discount make the large tubes unbeatable deals!
Great deal. Prevented diaper rash so far!

We use this after baths and limit baths to every couple of days because it can make the eczema worse. Also, we apply aquaphor at bedtime and keep our infant in the same PJs for a couple of wears, recommended by the dermatologist. The aquaphor absorbs into the clothes and keeps baby's skin extra moisturized. This routine isn't as helpful in the summer months because it is just too hot but it works great for the cooler months. My 2.5 year old has had eczema/very dry skin since he was born. We have used Aquaphor virtually every single day for the past 2 years and have found it to be superior to any other product. Our pediatrician recently gave us a tip to apply the Aquaphor immediately after bath time while his skin is still damp and I feel that's it the only OTC product that legitimately helps with this dry skin.

On the negative side, I will say that it's a bit messy. I don't think my son's clothes have held up too well since we're constantly dressing him on top of a fresh layer of Aquaphor. Same thing with my clothes, as I have gotten some greasy stains from my own hands or from holding him. We also have greasy marks on the walls by his changing table. This being said, you get used to it when you use it every day and it's worth it if it makes my son's skin feel better.

I know some say this is the same as regular Aquaphor, but I've found it to be a tad thicker in consistency. LOVE this product. It's the only thing that totally cures / prevents diaper rash for us. When my daughter has had a rash (she's 9 mos and has had two - both have been terrible) we wash her bottom with baby soap in sink (no wipes), air dry or pat with soft towel, then load her up with Aquaphor. Every single time. This alone cures the rash. And then when she doesn't have a rash, we use it to prevent by applying a thin layer to her bottom after each diaper change. Also use after bath in lieu of lotions as her skin is so sensitive (and this moisturizes so well).

review name: and we were recommended this product by several friends and the hospital for ...
review text:
First time mom, and we were recommended this product by several friends and the hospital for diaper rash. Our little one developed a nasty rash with blisters, and this product healed her within days. We tried all the other products like Drestin and Bert's Bees, but nothing compared to the amazing power of this product. You can use it for yourself as well. I got scratched by my cats, and applied this on it. Within the day, it was healed and no longer red.
If you have a baby with diaper rash, please buy this and apply liberally. It will leave a residue, but that is the point. It's meant to provide a protective barrier on your child's bum so protect against the urine and feces. They have a 6 hour guarantee I believe but give it a day or two to see improvement. Apply it after EVER diaper change (pee or poop) and you won't regret the purchase.

review name: Not just for Babies, Pressure sores be gone! SAVE MONEY, THIS IS SO MUCH LESS THAN BUYING LOCAL STORES!

It took months, several doctors, in home care, patches, hundreds in special pillows and specialty creams to make progress healing and our CNA said we should pick this up at the store (where it costs about 10x more for allot less) and she healed right up!

She said with the more gentle products he is less likely to have irritation which will help keep the heat rash at bay. She said that some kids are prone to rashes, but to use the best products I can to give him the best chance of avoiding them or at least only having small flare ups. I have been very happy with the results. There is a noticeable difference in the number and severity of the rashes since I have switched to both the Aquaphor healing ointment (that I use like lotion on him) and the Aquaphor baby wash. I definitely reccomend this to other families that have kids that are rash prone!

My daughter drooled a lot when she was a baby and she would get a rash under her chin, it didn't matter how many bibs we put on her or changed her clothes, she got a rash. This was a life saver, once we started using it on her chin, it went away quick, no rash. My son sucks on his fingers and his hands would get chapped so bad that they would bleed, so we put this on his hands at times he wasn't sleepy and about to suck on his finders and it made a big difference. He would cry if you put lotion on his hands, but this did the job fast. Then, I went to visit my friend who had a new baby and her daughter had a horrible diaper rash and she couldn't get rid of it, no matter what she tried, so I sent this as a gift along with a changing pee pad so she could let her air out some as well and this worked, it was such a relief because her daughter would cry every time she peed before from the pain. This was a miracle worker, the diaper rash was gone. I recommend it to all my friends!

This is the stuff you get and apply when you need to really bring out the big guns. When you're child-- despite your best efforts-- really breaks out with a diaper rash.

The main active ingredient in this is Vaseline / petroleum jelly, but it's also got mineral oil, ceresin, lanolin, panthenol, glycerin and bisabolol. There's something about those extra ingredients that gives it a more silky feel (a little thinner, easier to apply) and better healing properties. It's got a faint mediciny smell like Vick's Vapor Rub (although not nearly as strong).

Highly recommend this stuff. Thankfully we've only needed to apply it to our son once (over a few days). Broke our heart to see him with a diaper rash, but it cleared up in 2-3 days once we started applying this.

I had originally bought this (a small version) from my local retail store at the recommendation from a blog. A thick patch of skin had formed on my upper lip and so far nothing seemed to work to get it to go away. In fact some products actually dried my lips further, which was irritating. The patch was largely my fault. I've been on and off taking care of my lips mostly because I hated wearing anything on them and in general I don't wear makeup anyway. So when the patch showed up it was a wake up call that some habits need to change (like flossing more regularly, too).
So, I bought the Aquaphor. The nice thing about Aquaphor was that I only needed to apply twice, once in the morning and once at night. The moisturization lasts a long time, and I think especially since I live in a humid place although that day I was at work in AC which tends to dry out my lips. Took less than 48 hours then suddenly the rough patch pealed off on its own. I was so thrilled! I decided to try it on a few other akin conditions I had.
A zit that was forming on my chin I put tea tree oil and aquaphor. Tea tree by itself can take 3 days to see results, the aquaphor shaved off a day which was wonderful! Then I used it on my ears which tends to get redness and a little pealing on the back crease, and sometimes in the lobe. I believe it's psoriasis, but I never got it treated by a dermatologist (but then one time I went to one for acne the stuff they prescribed me made me nauseous). Well I put the aquaphor on and the next day I saw results. While there was still pealing, the redness had gone as well as the irritation. The inner lobes are healed up now and it looks like the rest will soon follow (it's day two using it on my ears). I had used a zinc cream before, and I had never gotten these results!
So, overall I'm very satisfied. It's a wonderful alternative to the many creams, lotions, lip balm, lip gloss, and moisturizers over the years. Heck I prescribe to Birchbox and have yet to find anything as effective! I don't even need much, a little really goes a long way and lasts for hours. Next I'll try my scalp and see if it helps with dandruff.

This stuff works, plain and simple. This was recommended by my daughters pediatrician when she showed sensitivity to certain lotions. I've used it since she was a few weeks old and haven't used anything else. It says healing and I feel it lived up to it, my daughter got very dry skin and I applied this everyday after her bath for only 2 days and I didn't need to apply the 3 day. Her skin was soft and hydrated. Unlike other lotions this will stop dry skin not just a quick fix for now. With diaper rash I apply at the first sign and it's gone, at most, within a day. Just a great over ointment for baby.

I don't purchase products like this from Amazon though, because I frequently see reviews where the product is suspected to be fake :( Amazon should really check the sources of beauty products better.

review name: The perfect multitasker to have in your medicine cabinet
review text: I was initially advised to use Aquaphor Baby by my little gir's pediatrician. My daughter had irritation on her next from breast milk. Just hours after application, the redness had subsided dramatically. We now use Aquaphor for all of her irritated skin issues. When she has a diaper rash we just pat the area, air dry and apply Aquaphor. The results have also been amazing. Now that she is drooling, we use it on her cheeks as a barrier and it has help avoid irritation there as well. I can't imagine not having it in our baby arsenal. I love that it multitasks for multiple baby problems and is not just a diaper rash cream. I highly recommend it to all my mama friends

review name: Container isn't ideal for baby diaper changes
review text: Aquaphor is what we've used on our baby since he was born over a year ago and we have never had any issues with rashes; the second one seems to be coming on, we're sure to put on a solid layer of Aquaphor and it's gone within a day. However, I much prefer the tube over this container. This is quite large and you have to fully twist off the lid, set the lid down, and prevent little hands from digging in. It's much easier to flip a tube open and snap it shut.

I'm a first time mom and my one month old has had a raw spot on his butt that wouldn't go away for a few weeks. The pediatrician was no help and I tried various creams, such as desitin and triple paste. Neither worked. I even tried using vaseline upon recommendation of some friends that are veteran parents. That also didn't help. Then I remembered Aquafor was sometimes used to help heal tattoos. My poor baby hated diaper changing until I found this product! I applied a thick layer right before bed time and the raw spot started clearing up over night. By day two, my baby is no longer screaming during diaper changes and the spot is completely gone.

We made a baby registry on Amazon when we found out we were having a baby. I found this product randomly from searching for things to add to the registry and chose to add it as well based on the high rating it had. Thankfully someone bought it for my baby shower, and I only wish I had known about it when I had my other two kids.

My older two children had very sensitive skin, got diaper rashes very easily, and my newest was no exception. Within a day of being born, he had a pretty bad rash. The hospital nurses kept giving me different creams to use, all containing zinc oxide. None of them improved the rash even a little (and zinc oxide had not worked well for my other two either.) When we got him home I started using the Aquaphor, the rash started getting better within a few hours, and it was completely gone in a little over a day. We use it at every diaper change, and there has been no sign of a rash since then. I do highly recommend this for treating and preventing diaper rashes!

review name: Best Petroleum-Based Ointment; Need to Really Look For Best Price
review text:
Here is the deal with Aquaphor. It is unequivocally the best petroleum-based ointment on the market. It goes on smooth and is not as greasy as its competitors and, with two kids, we have tried most, if not all.

The main issue then is really price. Target sells these jars for $17. If you can get them for under $15, great! If you can get them on Subscribe and Save for less, even better, but beware they are hit or miss and I have had my Subscribe and Save order cancelled due to it being out of stock semi-regularly.

Anyway, Aquaphor is the best, but it will cost you. The cheaper you can get it, obviously the better, and Amazon seems to be the leader in that regard, although I have seen it at Costco for $12.50 a jar once (I bought four jars), but then they were gone and I have yet to see a return (was it a mirage?) Hope this review helps someone.

We love this stuff post baby bath - lather the little kiddo up and the moisture is locked right into their skin! This tub will last a long time which is perfect because I hate shopping often! The product does not have a smell and is great for sensitive skin.

I bought this ointment after reading the hundreds of positive reviews and a recommendation from a friend, hoping it would help with my son's extremely dry skin patches... I can honestly say we gave it enough tries but it is just not doing anything for it. I also hate using it because it is just way too greasy, I feel like it just sits on top of the skin. I use it on him after bath/before bed time and it is nearly impossible to put his pjs on because his skin gets too sticky greasy from it, if that makes any sense. I would not mind it if it helped my child, but since it is not doing much I will be trying other brands.
Overall, there is certainly enough product to last awhile, I feel like it is a good value if it helps the skin issue, but might not be for everyone.

review name: There is nothing better than this to cure eczema.
review text:
My son suffers from severe eczema and it gets worst in cold weather . His pediatrician suggested to use this ointment on his body . We tried numerous products before this and they did not work on him so i was not very sure about this as well . Also we are very careful on what we use on his skin because we don't want anything to flare it up . As per his doctors suggestion we used Aquaphor twice a day once in the morning and once at night after this bath . Also it is very important that it is applied within 3 minutes after shower as it helps seal natural moisture of the body and does save his skin from drying out . This is the only product that has helped his skin condition. If we use it on him twice a day his eczema is nearly cured. It has worked so well on him that I started using it after I shower and it has made a tremendous difference in my skin. I don't have eczema but in the winter I end up with severe dry skin and this is the only moisturizer that made a difference.

The only downside to this ointment is that it goes on greasy and can take a few minutes for the greasiness to soak in. I prefer not to put on any good clothes right away in case some of the grease transfers to my clothes before it soaks into my skin. If there is a greasy spot or two on the clothing then using powder on the spots helps to get it out (let the powder sit on the greasy spot for a few minutes or more so it soaks up the oils, then brush the powder away). Even though it goes on greasy I decided to give it 5 stars because it is an 'ointment' rather than a 'moisturizer,' and it does what it is supposed to better than any other product we have tried.

Aquaphor is the ONLY ointment I use when changing my kid's diapers. Started using it years ago after a pediatrician recommended it to me for my son's horrible diaper rash. Cleared it right up and so much faster than other diaper creams out there! It's great at preventing and treating diaper rash. Definitely worth the money spent!

I have been applying this to my baby since day one and he never developed diaper rash. I change his diaper right after a poop or every couple hours but still in the night it will be longer in between each change. It comes in a huge jar and one can apply a large amount of cream as he wants

I use Aquaphor for everything...
1. Diaper Rash Prevention - I lather it on after every diaper change.
2. Heals Small Scrapes - I put it on after my infants scratches caused by his nails (nail cutting...an ongoing battle).
3. Lotion - I mix the Aquaphor and baby lotion together and give him infant massages with.

Additionally, I lather it on his feet and hands and cover with baby gloves and socks to prevent the skin pealing often found in infants. You may think it is too greasy, but I adjust how much I use based on the dryness of the skin except for diaper changes. For diaper changes, I use gobs of it and rub it in all his tiny fat rolls. My baby's skin is super soft and completely moisturized and so are my hands.

I purchased this product to use as a diaper cream and also for dry skin. I was unaware that this had the texture of vasiline which I'm not impressed with. I used it multiple times as a diaper cream and it has no results. Tried using it on my babies dry skin on her arms and also no results. The texture and residue of this product is awful and is even somewhat gritty. Definitely wouldn't recommend. Triple Paste is way better

You won't believe how well this stuff works on diaper rash. I actually bought it because my doctor recommended it for my son's eczema. It worked well on the eczema, but the astonishing thing was the diaper rash. I've been trying Mr. Smith's and Burt's Bees, but the poor kid maintained a nice red spot down there almost permanently. Then I tried this. Within hours he had no redness. I HIGHLY recommend this product. Just wish it didn't have mineral oil. Hopefully they will change that with the new research coming out about that yucky stuff. :-(

I have 6 month old twin boys which one has very sensitive skin. When we brought him from the hospital he had a small patch of what we were pretty sure was cradle cap. I kept my eye on it and treated it with various different things from olive oil to baby oil to the very expensive Calif. Baby to Selsan blue shampoo, all of which did nothing but make the problem worse. In fact, one day it's like his skin just exploded and the cradle cap became larger, more red and inflamed and he started getting patches of what looked like eczema, on his cheeks, torso and arms. My boy was miserable and not a happy camper. So off to the pediatrician we went. Our pediatrician was dumbfounded and was adamant it wasn't cradle cap and it was ring worm, even despite my telling him it was and he had it since day 1! So he prescribed 3 different kinds of creams, that were pretty harsh. I tried all 3 of them and NOTHING helped. In fact, again, it made the areas worse and seemed to sting my son. I was at a loss and frustrated until I read a post on a baby site that said Aquaphor works wonders. I had my husband rush out and get it and all I can say is WOW! this stuff is definitely a miracle in a jar! First day I applied this to my sons cradle cap on his head within hours the redness went down and it started getting smaller. Day 2 and it was completely gone! It's still working on the eczema on the rest of his body, but he's not as itchy, red or grumpy like he was. He seems way more comfortable. I am pissed I had to fight my pediatrician on this and spend a bunch of money on creams that were harsh and didn't work, but so glad I finally found a cure. I also bought Aquaphor gentle body and shampoo wash and only use that on my sons. It also helps tremendously. Buy it you will not be dissapointed!

review name: Mineral oil in this product ... BAD!!!
review text:
Very BAD ingredients... especially MINERAL OIL. "Mineral oil is a byproduct of gasoline and a cheap commodity for cosmetic and food manufacturers. Unfortunately, it also may be dangerous to one's health. According to the online Skin Deep Cosmetic Safety Database, there is strong evidence to suggest that mineral oil is an immune and respiratory intoxicant and is classified as toxic or harmful for organ systems."

Please, please research every ingredient in products placed on infants or children (skin absorbs everything really fast)... parabens and talc for instance cause cancer in lab mice. Formaldehyde is used on dead bodies. The list goes on...

After research, I found the best diaper cream, bath soap, wipes and diapers for us thus far. They have REALLY cute prints on the diapers too. The company is called "Honest". Check out will save you $10.00 off your first order for a FREE trial kit. That link will also give you $10.00 off your order. Free shipping if you purchase $50 or more from their website.
